{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = VidAngel | logo = VidAngel logo.png | type = Public | foundation = {{start date and age|2013}} | founder = Neal Harmon, Jeffrey Harmon, Daniel Harmon, and Jordan Harmon | location_city = [[Palo Alto, California]] | location_country = United States | area_served = United States | industry = Entertainment, [[Content-control software|Content filtering]] | homepage = {{ URL | 1=http://www.vidangel.com }} |alt = |caption = |key_people = | current_status = Active }} '''VidAngel''' is an American [[Streaming media|streaming video]] company that allows the user to skip distasteful content based on user preferences regarding profanity, nudity, sexual situations, and graphic violence.
Several big movie studios sued the company in 2016, claiming it broke copyright law by evading DVD copyright protection features and streaming altered videos without permission. In late 2016, the company was told to shut down its website until the trial. The company vowed to appeal, releasing a subscription-based app on [[Amazon Fire TV]], [[Roku]], [[Android TV]], and [[Apple TV]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865683232/VidAngels-CEO-explains-how-the-company-made-its-decision-to-develop-its-new-service.html|title=VidAngel's CEO explains how the company made its decision to develop its new service|last=Scribner|first=Herb|date=2017-06-19|publisher=Deseret News|accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref> for filtering [[Netflix]], [[Amazon Prime]], and [[HBO]] videos on June 13, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/biz/news/vidangel-netflix-amazon-filtering-launch-1202464295/|title=VidAngel Changes Course With New Netflix and Amazon Filtering Service|last1=Maddaus|first1=Gene|website=Variety|accessdate=June 17, 2017}}</ref>
The company filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] in October 2017.<ref name="Raymond2017">{{cite news|last1=Raymond|first1=Art|title=VidAngel files for bankruptcy protection — from its own customers|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/900002739/vidangel-files-for-bankruptcy-protection-from-its-own-customers.html|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Deseret News|date=23 October 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==History== VidAngel was founded in 2013 and launched in 2014 in [[Provo, Utah]] as a [[startup company]] with six employees.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McCord|first1=Keith|title=Provo company creates program that filters online content|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865609238/Provo-company-creates-program-that-filters-online-content.html?pg=all|website=Deseret News Utah|publisher=Deseret Digital Media|accessdate=October 20, 2016}}</ref> In March 2014, the company said it had moved its headquarters to [[Silicon Valley]], California.<ref>{{cite web|last1=VidAngel|title=Online Child Protection Startup VidAngel Moves Headquarters to Silicon Valley|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/online-child-protection-startup-vidangel-moves-headquarters-to-silicon-valley-1885769.htm|website=Market Wired|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref>
On August 11, 2016, during a legal deposition, Neal Harmon, VidAngel's CEO, said that VidAngel illegally ripped DVDs using the software program [[AnyDVD]] HD.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2017/08/24/16-56843.pdf|title=Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central District of California André Birotte, Jr., District Judge, Presiding|last=|first=|date=August 24, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cullins |first=Ashley |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/hollywood-studios-rip-vidangels-new-service-filtering-fight-1018550 |title=Hollywood Studios Rip VidAngel's New Service in Filtering Fight |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=2017-07-03 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hart |first=Terry |url=http://www.copyhype.com/2017/08/vidangel-vidangel-appeal-denied/ |title=VidAngel, VidAngel, Appeal Denied |publisher=Copyhype |date=2017-08-28 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref>
In December 2016, VidAngel began a Regulation A+ securities offering (mini [[initial public offering]]) to get $5 million in investments.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Alois|first1=JD|title=VidAngel Crowdfunded $5 Million in Just 28 Hours Under Reg A+|url=http://www.crowdfundinsider.com/2016/12/93321-vidangel-crowdfunded-5-million-just-28-hours-reg/|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Crowdfund Insider|date=4 December 2016}}</ref> It met its goal after 28 hours and had over $10 million after five days.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Turner|first1=Rod|title=VidAngel Boasts the Fastest Reg A+ Raise So Far|url=https://www.equities.com/news/vidangel-boasts-the-fastest-reg-a-raise-so-far|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Equities.com|date=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/digital/news/vidangel-raises-10-million-studio-copyright-lawsuit-1201914823/|title=Legally Embattled VidAngel Movie-Streaming Site Raises $10 Million From Fans|last=|first=|date=December 12, 2016|website=variety.com|publisher=Variety|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> They assigned 42% of the $10 million to advertising and 26% to legal costs.<ref>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BwbkppG95YDeSmdhM2l0Vjl3UHc/view VidAngel Offering Circular (Oct 19, 2016), pp. 23]</ref> Harmon Brothers, owned by VidAngel founders and officers Neal Harmon and Jeffery Harmon, will make the advertisements.<ref>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BwbkppG95YDeSmdhM2l0Vjl3UHc/view VidAngel Offering Circular (Oct 19, 2016), pp. 19]</ref>
In December 2016, VidAngel was ordered to shut down its website until the trial. Neal Harmon replied that VidAngel would open a studio in 2017 to make "family friendly" content.<ref name="variety1">{{cite news|last1=Maddaus|first1=Gene|title=Facing a Shutdown Order, VidAngel Will Start Making Movies|url=https://variety.com/2016/biz/news/vidangel-studio-fight-supreme-court-injunction-1201941655|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Variety|date=14 December 2016}}</ref>
In June 2017, shortly after the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals denied their request to lift the injunction, VidAngel announced a new streaming service for $7.99 per month (currently to filter content on [[Netflix]], [[Amazon Prime Video]], and [[HBO]]. Only titles from studios not included in the lawsuit are available.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cullins|first1=Ashley|title=VidAngel Launches New Platform Amid Studio Legal Battle (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/vidangel-launches-new-platform-studio-legal-battle-1013164|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=13 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> In a June 2017 statement, Netflix noted: "We have not endorsed or approved the VidAngel technology".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scribner|first1=Herb|title=Netflix says it has not 'endorsed or approved' VidAngel's new technology|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865683050/Netflix-has-not-endorsed-or-approved-VidAngels-new-technology.html|website=Deseret News|accessdate=June 17, 2017}}</ref>
Also in June 2017, VidAngel general council David Quinto made an unexpected admission that his client does indeed make master copies of Amazon content as VidAngel is incapable of posting any content on their site without an illegal master copy, as outlined in an article from Eriq Gardner (The Hollywood Reporter) who quoted the studios "[I]t appears from Mr. Quinto’s declaration that VidAngel itself is streaming from its own 'master' copies of works that VidAngel has created on its own servers rather than layering its filters over an authorized stream from the licensed streaming services," writes Glenn Pomerantz, attorney for the studios. "In other words, VidAngel indisputably itself is publicly performing works to its users."
==Operations== VidAngel allows users to personally select filters for moments that the user deems objectionable. Content, such as nudity, profanity, and graphic violence in commercial content, are skippable on the current VidAngel platform. The customer must purchase the content from select streaming services, that can be connected to VidAngel. When the user purchases the content they obtain the right to apply filters to objectionable content in their home.
===Legal basis=== VidAngel cites the [[Family Movie Act]] of 2005 (FMA) as legally protecting customers' right to use their service to filter films.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scribner|first1=Herb|title=Amid controversial court case, VidAngel makes the case for family friendly movies in new video|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865668411/Amid-controversial-court-case-VidAngel-makes-the-case-for-family-friendly-movies-in-new-video.html|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Deseret News|date=1 December 2016|language=en}}</ref> They say that under the FMA, they are allowed to stream filtered movies to customers as long as the movie is an authorized copy watched in the privacy of the home. As noted below, all these arguments have been rejected by the courts due to VidAngel's own legal counsel admitting that where they do not have agreements with Netflix and Amazon to use their movies and TV shows. In fact, VidAngel is not using authorized copies of any Netflix and Amazon content, but have to resort to making illegal master copies of all content from Netflix and Amazon in order to offer their current streaming service.
According to VidAngel, after they took their (DVD and Blu-ray based) movie-selling live for illegal public consumption -- without legal approval from any Hollywood movie studio -- they tried three different arrangements to legally sell movies in partnership with studios: teaming with [[Google]] to add filters to licensed films available on [[Google Play]]; buy a licensed movie on [[YouTube]] then apply filters to it; and buying discs directly from the studios. The studios rejected all three proposals, so VidAngel bought licensed discs from retail stores, made illegal master copies where they broke the anti-copying software on every DVD and Blu-ray disc they purchased and put their master copy of each movie on their website without studio-permission to use those movies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gardner|first1=Eriq|title=Hollywood Studios Are Suspicious of VidAngel's New Filtering App - Hollywood Reporter|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/hollywood-studios-are-suspicious-vidangels-new-filtering-app-1015521|website=Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=21 June 2017|language=en|date=21 June 2017}}</ref>
==Studio lawsuits== On June 12, 2016, production companies such as [[Lucasfilm]], [[20th Century Fox]], [[Disney Enterprises, Inc.]], and [[Warner Bros.]] filed a federal lawsuit against VidAngel for circumventing copyright protection on DVDs and for unlicensed video streaming, accusing them of violating the DMCA.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. DISTRICT COURT CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA WESTERN DIVISION CASE NO. CV16-04109|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/content.vidangel.com/VidAngel-Answer-and-Counter-Complaint.pdf|accessdate=October 20, 2016}}</ref> The case, ''Disney Enterprises, Inc. et al v. VidAngel, Inc.'', was filed in the [[United States District Court for the Central District of California]]. VidAngel's defense is that members actually own a digital copy of the film when they stream it for $20 and VidAngel will buy it back for $19 and have a right to filter content under the [[Family Entertainment and Copyright Act|Family Home Movie Act of 2005]]. VidAngel has filed a counterclaim against the companies alleging violation of the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]] and the preliminary hearing was held on November 14, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Openshaw|first1=Geoff|title=VidAngel Files Countersuit against Studios, Cites FMA Act|url=http://thisweekinmormons.com/2016/07/vidangel-files-countersuit-against-studios-cites-fma-act/|website=this week in mormons|publisher=This Week in Mormons|accessdate=October 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Porterfield|first1=Julia|title=Company sued for sanitizing films responds|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/aug/9/sanitizing-films-by-company-vidangel-sued-by-holly/|website=The Washington Times|accessdate=October 20, 2016}}</ref><ref name="deadline11142016">{{cite web |last=Cieply |first=Michael |url=http://deadline.com/2016/11/federal-judge-makes-no-decision-on-vidangel-injunction-1201854303/ |title=VidAngel Lawsuit: Judge Makes No Immediate Decision On Injunction |date=November 14, 2016 |work=Deadline |accessdate=November 26, 2016}}</ref>
In the lawsuit VidAngel is being represented by a group of lawyers led by Peter Stris of Stris & Maher, a small but influential firm known for handling complex cases and arguments at the Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leblanc |first=Jeanne |url=https://www.law.uconn.edu/about/press-room/professor-brendan-maher-prevails-us-supreme-court-case |title=Professor Brendan Maher Prevails in U.S. Supreme Court Case |publisher=UCONN School of Law |date=2016-05-25 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref> Disney is being represented by a group of lawyers led by former [[Solicitor General of the United States|Solicitor General]] [[Donald Verrilli]].<ref>{{cite news|title=VidAngel Tells 9th Circuit Studios Do Not Have Exclusive Streaming Rights - Lexis Legal News|url=http://www.lexislegalnews.com/articles/15110/vidangel-tells-9th-circuit-studios-do-not-have-exclusive-streaming-rights|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Lexis Legal News|date=24 February 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Judge [[Andre Birotte Jr.]], in a ruling on December 12, 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/334035673/VidAngel-ruling#from_embed|title=Vidangel ruling|last=|first=|date=December 12, 2016|website=Scribd|publisher=scribd.com|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> granted Disney's motion for a preliminary injunction, declaring that VidAngel had violated copyright laws by circumventing copyright protection technology on DVDs and by hosting the streamed content on VidAngel's computer servers without appropriate licensing and permission from copyright holders.<ref>Lauren A. McGee (2016) [http://biedermanblog.com/technology/12421/ Judge clips VidAngel’s naughty wings], The Biederman Blog, Southwestern Law School, Feb 3, 2017, accessed Aug 3, 2017 {{dead link|date=February 2018}}</ref> The court also rejected VidAngel's [[Fair Use]] defense, noting as paraphrased in media about the case, "VidAngel does not add anything and the result has essentially the same entertainment value as the original, thus the fair use defense is unlikely to win out."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Eggerton|first1=John|title=Court Blocks VidAngel Video Filtering Service {{!}} Broadcasting & Cable|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/washington/court-blocks-vidangel-video-filtering-service/161750|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=www.broadcastingcable.com|date=13 December 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Judge Birotte's order blocked VidAngel from circumventing copyright protection features on DVDs and also ordered them to stop streaming movies, stating that the Family Movie Act requires that the filtered content comes from an "authorized copy" of the film, and the digital content VidAngel streamed was not an authorized copy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox13now.com/2016/12/12/federal-judge-blocks-utah-based-vidangel-from-filtering-movies/|title=Federal judge blocks Utah-based VidAngel from filtering movies|last=|first=|date=December 12, 2016|website=Fox 13 Now|publisher=Fox13 TV News|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, VidAngel requested a stay of the preliminary injunction, claiming the company would suffer irreparable legal harm from not being able to operate while the case makes its way through the courts. VidAngel has vowed to fight the case all the way to the [[United States Supreme Court]].<ref name="variety1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/vidangel-ceo-statement-on-preliminary-injunction-decision-in-disney-v-vidangel-case-300376972.html|title=VidAngel CEO Statement on Preliminary Injunction Decision in Disney v. VidAngel Case|last=|first=|date=December 12, 2016|website=prnewswire.com|publisher=|access-date=December 12, 2016}}</ref> VidAngel announced intentions to obey the court's order to stop streaming effective December 30, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |last=Scribner |first=Herb |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865670178/VidAngel-has-temporarily-stopped-streaming-filtered-movies-Here7s-why.html |title=VidAngel has temporarily stopped streaming filtered movies. Here's why |date=December 30, 2016 |work=Deseret News |accessdate=December 31, 2016}}</ref> However, in January 2017, VidAngel was found in contempt of court for continuing to add titles in violation of the court's order. For this infraction, they were fined $10,231.20 in legal costs incurred by Disney et al.<ref>{{cite web|first=Ben |last=Winslow |url=http://fox13now.com/2017/01/06/vidangel-fined-10000-for-contempt-of-court-in-movie-filtering-lawsuit/ |title=VidAngel fined $10,000 for contempt of court in movie filtering lawsuit |publisher=Fox 13 |date=2017-01-06 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref> After this ruling, Johnathan Bailey of ''Plagiarism Today'' wrote that VidAngel's public statements have consistently misrepresented the core legal issues in the case by characterizing the major film studios as opposed primarily to filtering adult content: "[T]he studios have repeatedly made it clear that the filtering is not the issue, its the unauthorized streaming and copy protection circumvention, nothing more."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bailey|first1=Jonathan|title=VidAngel: It's Not About Filtering - Plagiarism Today|url=https://www.plagiarismtoday.com/2017/01/12/vidangel-important-case-dont-know/|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Plagiarism Today|date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
VidAngel appealed the case to the [[Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]]. A hearing occurred June 8, 2017, where VidAngel requested an emergency stay of the injunction. VidAngel's request was denied and the injunction was upheld.<ref>{{cite web|author=TV News Desk |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/VidAngel-Responds-to-9th-Circuit-Decision-20170105# |title=VidAngel Responds to 9th Circuit Decision |publisher=BroadwayWorld |date=2017-01-05 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref>
VidAngel requested an appeal or clarification of the injunction, specifically whether their new streaming-filter service was a violation of the injunction. Disney et al. responded with a request for an ''[[ex parte]]'' ruling, arguing that VidAngel violated procedural rules by not notifying Disney of their intentions of filing such an appeal or clarification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.vidangel.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Ex-Parte-Application.pdf |title=PLAINTIFFS' ''EX PARTE'' APPLICATION FOR AN ORDER [1] STRIKING VIDANGEL'S MOTION TO CLARIFY [DKT. NO. 182] FOR FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH LOCAL RULE 7-3 AND [2] SETTING SCHEDULE FOR RE- NOTICED MOTION THAT INCLUDES DISCOVERY ON VIDANGEL'S "NEW" STREAMING SERVICE |publisher= |date=2017-06-20 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref> On August 2, 2017, Judge Birotte rejected VidAngel's request for appeal or clarification of the injunction.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/public/case/12096022/Disney_Enterprises,_Inc_et_al_v_VidAngel_Inc |title=Disney Enterprises, Inc. et al v. VidAngel Inc. (2:16-cv-04109), California Central District Court |publisher=Pacermonitor.com |date= |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Raymond|first1=Art|title=VidAngel request for injunction review rejected|url=https://www.ksl.com/?sid=45273989&nid=1012&title=vidangel-request-for-injunction-review-rejected|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=KSL.com|date=3 August 2017|language=en}}</ref>
On August 24, 2017 the [[Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] upheld the injunction against VidAngel, quoting a statement from U.S. Senator [[Orrin Hatch]] that the Family Movie Act is not a defense for violation of copy protection measures or for violation of copyright law, and to suggest otherwise is "counter to legislative intent" of the Family Movie Act.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stempel|first1=Jonathan|title=Hollywood studios win ruling over VidAngel family-friendly filters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-vidangel-studios-lawsuit-idUSKCN1B42AR|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Reuters|date=2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Raymond |first=Art |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865687538/Ninth-Circuit-Court-of-Appeals-rejects-VidAngels-injunction-appeal.html |title=9th Circuit Court of Appeals rejects VidAngel's injunction appeal |publisher=Deseret News |date=2017-08-25 |accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref>
In September 2017, VidAngel filed its own lawsuit in a Utah federal court against affiliates of the studios, including [[Marvel Comics]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company]], [[Castle Rock Entertainment]], [[MGM Studios]], and others, seeking a [[declaratory judgment]] that its new streaming model is legal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gardner|first1=Eriq|title=VidAngel Seeks Salvation for Filtering Service in Utah Federal Court|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/vidangel-seeks-salvation-filtering-service-utah-federal-court-1034581|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|issue=01 September 2017|language=en}}</ref> After VidAngel reportedly decided to drop the case, U.S. District Court Judge [[David Nuffer]] dismissed this lawsuit on August 7, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |last=Winslow |first=Ben |url=https://fox13now.com/2018/08/07/vidangel-drops-lawsuit-against-hollywood-studios/ |title=VidAngel drops lawsuit against Hollywood studios |date=7 August 2018 |publisher=Fox 13 Salt Lake City |accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref>
In October 2017, VidAngel filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection]] as a legal strategy to protect the company against the ongoing lawsuit and allow it to reorganize its business around its new streaming service in an effort to ensure that they could avoid the courts from declaring how much VidAngel owed the studios in copyright infringment fines for as long as possible.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Legal Entertainment|title=VidAngel Uses Bankruptcy Strategy To Fend Off Studios|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/legalentertainment/2017/10/18/vidangel-uses-bankruptcy-strategy-to-fend-off-studios/|accessdate=25 February 2018|work=Forbes|date=18 October 2017|language=en}}</ref> VidAngel estimated between $1 million and $10 million in liabilities, and approximately equal amounts of assets.<ref name="Raymond2017"/> The filing forces a pause on the lawsuit, but allows business to continue as usual. A statement on the company's blog announced: "VidAngel is not going away", that the company has "millions of dollars in the bank, and now generating millions in revenue," and stated its goal was "to reorganize the business around our new streaming model" to stay in business and pay damages when they finally lose the pending trial.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harmon|first1=Neal|title=VidAngel Uses Chapter 11 Protection to Pause Los Angeles Lawsuit to Reorganize Its Business Around The New Streaming Model - VidAngel Blog|url=http://blog.vidangel.com/2017/10/18/vidangel-uses-chapter-11-protection-pause-los-angeles-lawsuit-reorganize-business-around-new-streaming-model/|publisher=VidAngel|accessdate=25 February 2018|date=18 October 2017}}</ref> The plaintiffs in the lawsuit characterized the bankruptcy as a delay tactic, noting that prior rulings indicate VidAngel would indefinitely lose in court.<ref name="Raymond2017"/> An article in Utah's ''Deseret News (''https://www.deseretnews.com/article/900002739/vidangel-files-for-bankruptcy-protection-from-its-own-customers.html) further notes that the bankruptcy has provoked ire among some customers whose buy-back credits for DVD purchases are included in the bankruptcy among VidAngel's assets, preventing customers from cashing out these refunds while the bankruptcy is pending.<ref name="Raymond2017"/>
